Posts.Content: God speed, Gsteve! See you on the other side. Good luck and stay positive! You'll be walking down the hall with your IV pole before you know it. Fran

Posts.Title: Blood tests done. Di.vinci at 10am tues

Posts.Content: Logic, you will do fine and be fine! I had never been in the hospital a day in my life. No broken bones, no stitches, no nothing. I found my self looking forward to the surgery to get it behind me. Think of it that way and you may find it easier in the few days ahead. This forum really helped me to understand what was about to happen and on the other side. I have always had a pretty high tolerance for pain so the surgery pain did not overwhelm me and it is certainly tolerable. The one thing that got to me right out of the gate and was the most unpleasant part of the whole ordeal was the catheter. Make friends with it right from the get-go and you will be fine. Take a steady diet of stool softener like Metamucil until your first BM and things will go smoothly! (Pun intended) Good luck and see you on the other side. Fran

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Us guys who are still having major ED issues are quite envious of you guys (both young and old) who are enjoying satisfactory erections! Some of us who had problems from BPH prior to surgery are still struggling. I am almost 8 months post nerve sparing surgery and I am not having any success, even with Viagra help. I am doing maintenence viagra every week and using the pump to some degree of success but hoping that things improve with time and I get back some function. Only time will tell, I guess. Fran

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club, Outdoors! Sorry you have to join at such a young age. Great life experiences here in this club. You will get a world of knowledge from some of the members here. As Chuck so often tells people, the biopsy only samples about 1/1000th of the prostate so in your case, there is likely a lot going on and of an aggressive nature. You are wise to seek treatment relatively quickly. Do your research, pick a treatment that is best for you and don't look back. Many of us here were lucky enough to find our cancer early and have become members of our Zero Club. Here's hoping you get to join that club as well. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: just recently found out that my father has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you had to join the club! IMHO you are correct in choosing surgery. Hopefully it was found early enough a surgery will, like myself, leave you cancer free. I too found it difficult to choose a surgeon. Living less than an hour from Boston gave me a wealth of experienced surgeons to choose from. In the end, I choose my own urologist to perform the daVinci surgery mainly because I trusted him and was confident he had enough experience and skill to do the job. Living 5 minutes from the hospital was a plus. I have read some good things about Dr.Tewari, but if you choose him, or anyone else for that matter, make sure they are doing the actual surgery and not one of their assistants! Good luck and keep posting on your decisions and progress. You can learn valuable tips here and you can help others on their journey as well. Fran

Posts.Title: Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer - choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Welcome! My guess would be the additional tests are hard to justify considering their costs. With a negative DRE and marginally high PSA that has fluctuated down considerably, your uro is not very confident in finding any cancer. I had three biopsies over some years before my G7 Cancer was detected and only then was scans and MRI warranted. In all case, the biopsy was triggered by a positive DRE combined with PSA results. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Newcomer - Recovering three days after RALRP

Posts.Content: Welcome Brock, sorry you had to join our little club. You have come to a great place for insight and advice. Most here who have been through the surgery will tell you that you will feel remarkably better as the days and weeks go by. Take it slow, walk when you can to get and keep things moving, keep doing those Kegels and stay positive. You will undoubtedly get frustrated when you start to feel really good but your incontinence or ED issue don't seem to be progressing. Be patient as it takes much time for your body to recover from this ordeal. Good luck! Fran

Posts.Title: Newcomer - Recovering three days after RALRP

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum and our little club, Creekrat. You are correct about the DRE...as unpleasant as it is, it is also very good diagnostic tool for a urologist in finding out what is going on with your Prostate. Mine used it more than PSA results in determining whether a biopsy was needed. Had three biopsies before my G7 Cancer was detected but early enough that after my daVinci surgery has left me, hopefully, cancer free. NJ1116 is correct. You need to be in good condition to tolerate the surgery. Radiation is just as good a treatment so do your research, pick a treatment option and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: What doctors are best at MD Anderson

Posts.Content: Logic, you will do fine and be fine! I had never been in the hospital a day in my life. No broken bones, no stitches, no nothing. I found my self looking forward to the surgery to get it behind me. Think of it that way and you may find it easier in the few days ahead. This forum really helped me to understand what was about to happen and on the other side. I have always had a pretty high tolerance for pain so the surgery pain did not overwhelm me and it is certainly tolerable. The one thing that got to me right out of the gate and was the most unpleasant part of the whole ordeal was the catheter. Make friends with it right from the get-go and you will be fine. Take a steady diet of stool softener like Metamucil until your first BM and things will go smoothly! (Pun intended) Good luck and see you on the other side. Fran

Posts.Content: Us guys who are still having major ED issues are quite envious of you guys (both young and old) who are enjoying satisfactory erections! Some of us who had problems from BPH prior to surgery are still struggling. I am almost 8 months post nerve sparing surgery and I am not having any success, even with Viagra help. I am doing maintenence viagra every week and using the pump to some degree of success but hoping that things improve with time and I get back some function. Only time will tell, I guess. Fran

Posts.Title: Blood tests done. Di.vinci at 10am tues

Posts.Content: Welcome! My guess would be the additional tests are hard to justify considering their costs. With a negative DRE and marginally high PSA that has fluctuated down considerably, your uro is not very confident in finding any cancer. I had three biopsies over some years before my G7 Cancer was detected and only then was scans and MRI warranted. In all case, the biopsy was triggered by a positive DRE combined with PSA results. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Questions to ask Pre-Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you had to join the club! IMHO you are correct in choosing surgery. Hopefully it was found early enough a surgery will, like myself, leave you cancer free. I too found it difficult to choose a surgeon. Living less than an hour from Boston gave me a wealth of experienced surgeons to choose from. In the end, I choose my own urologist to perform the daVinci surgery mainly because I trusted him and was confident he had enough experience and skill to do the job. Living 5 minutes from the hospital was a plus. I have read some good things about Dr.Tewari, but if you choose him, or anyone else for that matter, make sure they are doing the actual surgery and not one of their assistants! Good luck and keep posting on your decisions and progress. You can learn valuable tips here and you can help others on their journey as well. Fran

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum and our little club, Creekrat. You are correct about the DRE...as unpleasant as it is, it is also very good diagnostic tool for a urologist in finding out what is going on with your Prostate. Mine used it more than PSA results in determining whether a biopsy was needed. Had three biopsies before my G7 Cancer was detected but early enough that after my daVinci surgery has left me, hopefully, cancer free. NJ1116 is correct. You need to be in good condition to tolerate the surgery. Radiation is just as good a treatment so do your research, pick a treatment option and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Erections Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome Brock, sorry you had to join our little club. You have come to a great place for insight and advice. Most here who have been through the surgery will tell you that you will feel remarkably better as the days and weeks go by. Take it slow, walk when you can to get and keep things moving, keep doing those Kegels and stay positive. You will undoubtedly get frustrated when you start to feel really good but your incontinence or ED issue don't seem to be progressing. Be patient as it takes much time for your body to recover from this ordeal. Good luck! Fran

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side, JD1969! You will soon be farting up a storm, releasing all that gas they pumped into you. You will probably be home soon and will get to sleep in your own bed or recliner. In a couple of days or so you will have your first bowel movement which will be one of a long list of emotional experiences along this journey. I had my first one after about 4 days then took my first shower...had tears streaming down my face it felt so good! Push yourself to walk as much as possible to help keep everything moving. Then soon you will be looking forward to the catheter removal! Good luck! Fran

Posts.Content: Don't get too hung up on your psa number. It's just a number. Your urologist will use it along with it's trend and rate of change (sometimes referred to as doubling time) along with DRE's to try to gauge what is going on. Trust your doctor (or if you don't, find one you do) and retest in January along with another DRE (after the blood draw) and go from there. Fran

Posts.Title: 45 yrs old, PSA=2.45...neep a pep talk

Posts.Content: Welcome, Popi. You will get some excellent insight and advice here. Did you have a DRE (digital rectal exam) as part of your urologist visit? If you did I would guess it did not show anything out of the ordinary. If it had been abnormal, your urologist would probably have recommended a biopsy as the next step. I would not worry too much about your psa numbers. You are right that sex, bike riding, exercise, etc. can spike your psa. Keep an eye on it and continue to have dre's looking for abnormalities. As far as your surgeon, most here recommend that you find one that has done at least 500 daVinci prostatectemies. As Highlander, an administrator here who is sure to chime in, likes to say, you only get one shot at this! Many of us here felt the same way as you. When cancer was found remove it as soon possible! Good luck, stay positive, and we all hope you don't have to join our club. Or if you do, not any time soon. Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club, Peter! You are right that this forum helps many through this ordeal. I often see many signed on to the forum, but few posters and often wondered who was lurking and getting help by just reading. You will find that you will make great strides in the months to come. I am coming up on 5 months post surgery and it's almost like it never happened. LOL You will get frustrated at times as your mind thinks you should be doing better than you are, but take it slow and easy as the trauma of the surgery takes more out of you than you think! Good luck, stay positive, and here's hoping you join the Zero Club that Highlander speaks of! Fran

Posts.Content: Chuck is indeed spot on about the catheter. I found the smaller leg bag to be far more trouble than it was worth and pretty much used the large collection bag exclusively. I would say the key is to have a good attachment of the tube to your upper leg. That holds the tube in a comfortable position. I have a nurse in my family who got me every conceivable item to make the attachment. They make a special velcro strap specifically for the catheter tube that tapes to your leg and I found that to worked best for me. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome Donald. Sorry about your urination issues. Like Chuck, I had severe BPH which eventually turned into cancer and after daVinci surgery, I am cancer free and peeing like a racehorse . Most comments above are spot on. In addition, I would add that I was on Avodart for a number of years and had no adverse side affects. In addition, there is a procedure to essentially Rotorooter your urethra, which will open up the passage where the prostate is squeezing it shut. That may be in your future. It seems to me that 15 years is an awful long time to have BPH, so like the others I am interested to know your age. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club, Felix. If you haven't already, you should get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's " Surviving Prostate Cancer" You will find a wealth of info about the disease and many statistics. It is true that no two cases are alike. A recent poster was dismayed that his father passed away inside a year after being diagnosed with G6 pc. That is said not to scare you but to point out the vagaries of the disease and it's diagnosis and treatment. It is a somewhat inaccurate science. It is what leads some of us to choose surgery...to hopefully cut it out and remove all traces from the body. Sometimes it works and other times it doesn't. Good luck in your research and treatment choice. We are all here for you. Fran

Posts.Title: Post Op - Day 1

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walt_Green not to pic nits here, but the OP did Watchful Wait, not Active Surveillance. there is a very big difference! Unless I read it incorrectly, he went 2 years (perhaps 3?) in between biopsies, and only had PSA's every 6 months. IIRC, AS requires yearly biopsies as well as PSA tests every three months. As for the OP, I would recommend a he get second opinion on the G8 scoring. His PSA is *extremely* low for his age. Even if scaled back to a G7a or 7b, he should still treat, of course. But, there's a world of difference between G7a/b or G8. For those quick to criticize WW/AS, the OP has had three years of normal life. His scans are negative. Even if he has to treat now, he's LOST NOTHING. on the other hand, he has gained THREE YEARS OF NORMAL LIFE. Given his age, his WW was a smart play. He's lost nothing, only gained. I don't give a lot of weight to negative scans. It has been said many times here that the scans don't show anything unless any tumor is large. There still could micrometastisis that no scan will detect. Fran

Posts.Title: active watch for 2 years and now gleason 8...what now

Posts.Content: Welcome, Gurley 43. Sorry you are joining the club. You will get great insight and support here. I had similar psa numbers when my cancer was detected this past May. At 62 and with excellent health my choice was surgery and having found it early, I'm confident that I am now and will remain cancer free. Only time will tell. I'm not sure I would make the same treatment choice if I had been 70, but I'm pretty sure I would. Gleason 8 is pretty aggressive so whatever you decide, you should move quickly. I had a good friend who had the seeds implanted at 70. He was not in as good physical condition as I and I'm not sure of his Gleason score or psa but he has done well for 5 years now. There are lots of options. If you haven't already, get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is one of the bibles on the subject. Others will likely chime in with more advice. Good luck Fran

Posts.Content: Good luck, Gurley! There are a number of posters here who had their surgery done my Dr. Patel with excellent results. If you are in reasonably good physical condition you should tolerate the surgery with little problem. Incontinence and ED are definite side effects. I am still leaking pretty good at 3 months post surgery, but I am happy to be cancer free and would not have done anything differently. I would try to exercise as much as possible and do your Kegel exercises to prepare for the surgery. Keep us posted and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Frank, I expect your doctor has you on Viagra or Cialis. If it is not working effectively, I would recommend asking him about injection therapy. Posts.Title: I'm Coping with Post-Surgery Changes

Posts.Content: Welcome K9. NJS is correct . The three tests that all urologists use are the psa, DRE, and the needle biopsy. If one is suspect they go to the next and so on. The tricky part is, although rare, you can have pc with a low psa number and a normal DRE. My psa at 63 with and an abnormal DRE was 2.9 and pc was found at the third biopsy over 6 years. I guess the point is keep testing using all the tests available. If you have pc you want to find it and treat it early. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Hang in there, Vern, it does get better...and pretty quickly. You are right, the catheter was by far the worst part of the ordeal for me. And I was lucky enough ?? to have it in for 12 days as that is my doctors typical protocol! I just used loose fitting shorts (it was the summer) and sweat pants and let the tube run inside the waist band and then down. My nurse daughter-in-law hooked me up with some velcro sticky pads specially made for the catheter tube and they worked great. Good luck with catheter removal tomorrow, guys. Piece of cake! Bring a pair of pad briefs with you as most have little control right after removal. Fran

Posts.Content: Bill, I had my 6 week follow up visit with my urologist today. He said I was doing great and to just keep doing Kegels. He prescribed a drug for helping with bladder control. I was also surprised to learn that some of the sutures that he used to tie the bladder to the urethra probably have not dissolved yet so as that happens, expect more and more control....interesting. I also realized later that I avoided coffee altogether today(quite by accident) so that helped play a role in me staying dry this morning. Fran

Posts.Content: Bill, I had my 6 week follow up visit with my urologist today. He said I was doing great and to just keep doing Kegels. He prescribed a drug for helping with bladder control. I was also surprised to learn that some of the sutures that he used to tie the bladder to the urethra probably have not dissolved yet so as that happens, expect more and more control....interesting. I also realized later that I avoided coffee altogether today(quite by accident) so that helped play a role in me staying dry this morning. Fran

Posts.Content: I am just over 5 weeks post surgery and 3 weeks post catheter removal and I have little bladder control. Sleeping at night or while sitting, I do not leak. Getting a little frustrated at the lack of progress. Fran

I wonder if the average person could! Fran

Posts.Title: Itching

Posts.Content: Welcome to our little club, Mike. Hope they found that G8 early and surgery makes you a member of our Zero Club! The penis shortening thing is real. It reminds me of a penis that has not been circumcised. As you might expect, it is particularly noticeable when you have been in cold weather. I find myself making sure the head is poking out before I urinate, or I risk a wayward stream. I would imagine that your large prostate wasn't always that way and it will have less of an effect than you think. The vas are left to empty into your abdomen, to be absorbed by the body, if I understand it correctly. There is the possibility that an ejaculate might occur from small glands left behind (Highlander, an administrator here, speaks of them often) but not in my case as mine are truly dry . Some here speak of orgasms that are as powerful or more powerful than prior to surgery but also not in my case as mine are more subtle than before. If I can offer just one bit of advice it would be to be patient. The surgery takes more out of you than you think. You will find yourself frustrated at the slow progress of incontinence and ED. Be patient as it takes months, not weeks to recover. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: New Member with Questions and some observations

Posts.Content: Moe, Sorry you might be joining our club! Seems like you are on top of your situation. I too was 63 when my 3rd biopsy found cancer. I choose daVinci surgery and just had my 5 year PSA showing 0 and still cancer free. My Gleason score was 7 and biopsy found it on one lobe only. Funny thing is final pathology showed both lobes involved so biopsies can miss cancer as they are sampling such a minute amount of tissue. Not to alarm you, but in the same vain, a very good friend at 53 years old that had virtually the same stats as I going into surgery had G9 cancer that had spread and he is going through radiation now. Get all your tests and with a urologist you trust, make an informed decision on your treatment, which could include active surveillance. Good luck and keep us up to date on your progress. Fran

Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions. Surgery or remain on AS with Gleason 3+4

Posts.Content: Evilene, welcome. You have come to the right place. You will get great insight, knowledge, and experience from the members here. Fairwind is correct. Definitely get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Otago is correct that psa is not a reliable predictor of pca in and of itself. You will see below my psa at cancer diagnosis was 2.9. And although the needle biopsy finds cancer when it exists most of the time when present, it can miss it. MRI and scans usually are done after because they are less accurate in finding minute amounts of cancer. It is a combination of all of these tests including the DRE that give the urologist the overall picture of what is going on. Hopefully, the biopsy will be clean and medication will get that psa going in the other direction. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: Evilene, welcome. You have come to the right place. You will get great insight, knowledge, and experience from the members here. Fairwind is correct. Definitely get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Otago is correct that psa is not a reliable predictor of pca in and of itself. You will see below my psa at cancer diagnosis was 2.9. And although the needle biopsy finds cancer when it exists most of the time when present, it can miss it. MRI and scans usually are done after because they are less accurate in finding minute amounts of cancer. It is a combination of all of these tests including the DRE that give the urologist the overall picture of what is going on. Hopefully, the biopsy will be clean and medication will get that psa going in the other direction. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: My Husband has triple digit PSA

Posts.Content: Moe, Sorry you might be joining our club! Seems like you are on top of your situation. I too was 63 when my 3rd biopsy found cancer. I choose daVinci surgery and just had my 5 year PSA showing 0 and still cancer free. My Gleason score was 7 and biopsy found it on one lobe only. Funny thing is final pathology showed both lobes involved so biopsies can miss cancer as they are sampling such a minute amount of tissue. Not to alarm you, but in the same vain, a very good friend at 53 years old that had virtually the same stats as I going into surgery had G9 cancer that had spread and he is going through radiation now. Get all your tests and with a urologist you trust, make an informed decision on your treatment, which could include active surveillance. Good luck and keep us up to date on your progress. Fran

Posts.Title: Should I start chemo?

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry to hear you are joining our little club. Although G6 cancer is less aggressive, I'm guessing the family history of PC is pushing you towards aggressive treatment. Fairwind is correct in stating 300 surgeries is a minimum base line for a surgeon to be considered experienced. Obviously, more surgeries, more experienced but you could also look at your particular surgeons results concerning complications and speak to some of his patients if allowed. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Sex after surgery -- positive outcomes

Posts.Content: All are stearing you in the right direction. Your mind thinks you are far more healed than you really are! My urologist told me it could take a month or more just for the internal sutures to dissolve. Take it slow and easy for a month and try to concentrate on healing. And look to become frustrated as the pace of healing and continence slows. It takes a LONG time to be fully healed. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: My kingdom for a fart !!

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing, Ralph. Glad to see that it has worked out well for you. I consider myself in a very similar place. Like you, we found my cancer very early and I am and should remain cancer free. Slight incontinence persists but is improving and ED is still a major issue, but I had issues before surgery from BPH and being 63, it is to be expected. I feel great and am in a good place physically as well as emotionally. I have tremendous support from my family and co-workers and this forum was also invaluable in helping me through the ordeal. This firefighter from Massachusetts says stay safe out there Sargeant! Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer: Diagnosis to treatment - Here is my story

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the news about your dad, LisaN. You are to be commended for being an advocate for him. Posts.Title: My dad's prostate cancer is back. Now what?

Posts.Content: All are stearing you in the right direction. Your mind thinks you are far more healed than you really are! My urologist told me it could take a month or more just for the internal sutures to dissolve. Take it slow and easy for a month and try to concentrate on healing. And look to become frustrated as the pace of healing and continence slows. It takes a LONG time to be fully healed. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed--report from the wife

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing, Ralph. Glad to see that it has worked out well for you. I consider myself in a very similar place. Like you, we found my cancer very early and I am and should remain cancer free. Slight incontinence persists but is improving and ED is still a major issue, but I had issues before surgery from BPH and being 63, it is to be expected. I feel great and am in a good place physically as well as emotionally. I have tremendous support from my family and co-workers and this forum was also invaluable in helping me through the ordeal. This firefighter from Massachusetts says stay safe out there Sargeant! Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer: Diagnosis to treatment - Here is my story

Posts.Content: I would get the full briefs to start. Maybe one package to see how it goes for the first week. If you are like most of us, you will leak heavily at first, then less and less quickly until recovery starts to slow. You may then get frustrated that it is not going as quickly as you think it should. Be patient...it was almost a year to the day that I was able to not use any protection at all. It is major surgery with major reconstruction to your plumbing! It takes time to heal. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Living and Loving Life

Posts.Content: Sorry for your dad's pain and worry. You have come to a great site for knowledge and insight. How old is he? I wonder by taking everything that included the nerves that control erections? I am coming up on 9 weeks post surgery. I did not have any of the testicle pain your dad suffers from but have heard it mentioned here. I have never seen the foot pain described here but that doesn't mean it hasn't as I'm pretty new to this club. Others will certainly chime in. I would expect that your dad, much like I have, will be recovered very quickly and pretty much back to his old hard working self. Other than slow recovery in the incontinence department, and still waiting for the ED issue to come around, I feel 100% and am doing everything I did before surgery. Good luck to your dad and congrats to you for looking for answers for him. Fran

Posts.Title: Slaon-Kettering Video: Penile Rehabiliation

Posts.Content: Welcome To the club, Rob. How is your incontinence and ED going? I had my surgery on July 17th. I am down to one pad a day with a light pad that stays completely dry at night. ED is more an issue as nothing is happening in that regard even with Viagra. I had issues before surgery which Viagra helped so I'm hoping to get back to at least what I had before surgery. Good luck and stay positive. Fran
Posts.Signature: BD 1950 DRE in 2005 showed right lobe enlarged/hard Biopsies in 2006 and 2009 both negative Biopsy May 2013 positive 1 of 14 cores 4+3=7 T2a. PSA 2.9 daVinci surgery 7/17/13 by Dr. Dennis LaRock Final pathology 7/29/13 Tumor size 1.5 cm PC found on both lobes (biopsy indicated one) T2b Gleason 4+3=7 Negative margins first post surgery psa 8/30/13 undetectable second post surgery psa 11/23/13 undetectable 18 month post surgery psa 2/17/15 undetectable 5 year post surgery psa 3/20/18 undetectable
Posts.Title: Ectopic ureter

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side. Things will progress at a pretty rapid pace at first and then tail off as time goes on. Keep walking as much as possible to help circulation and keep things moving. Good luck and stay positive. It has been 18 months since my daVinci and it's almost like it never happened. Fran

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas

Posts.Content: After your explanation of what the doctor said, it obviously was an 80. It would be in his best interest to have that biopsy done and then decide on a course of action depending on what is found. Even if some cancer is found, it is possible that no treatment at all could be recommended depending on the amount and aggressiveness of the cancer. Try to persuade him to have the test done and you both will have a better idea where he stands. Good luck.

Posts.Content: For me, choosing my surgeon came down to how familiar my urologist was with me AND being 10 minutes from home was more important than traveling to a world class facility to have someone operate on me that I was unfamiliar with and vice versa. It all comes down to what decision are YOU comfortable with! As is said by many on this forum, once you deliberate, then decide, don't look back! Good Luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Content: All you can do is stay on top of your situation , and you are certainly doing that! After results are in, deal with what ever hand you are delt. I followed that exact path and after third biopsy found G7 Cancer, decided on daVinci surgery and coming up on two years and still cancer free. Here's hoping you are Cancer free, but if not, there are options available to deal with it. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome to our little club, Paul. Sorry you had to join. You will get great knowledge and insight on this site from many who have been through this ordeal. If surgery ends up your plan of action, it will not occur until 6-8 weeks after your biopsy to allow for that to heal. There is life after Prostate surgery, so take heart in that fact. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: 1 year anniversary

Posts.Content: Enzo, if you learn anything anything along the way, it will be that no two prostate cancers are the same. A very high PSA doesn't necessarily mean cancer and a low PSA doesn't mean there is no cancer. A combination of tests of PSA , DRE, and a needle biopsy are used to determine a cancerous prostate and even then, the most definitive test, the biopsy, can occasionally miss the cancer. The combination of the PSA and DRE are used by the doctor to determine if a biopsy is needed and to establish a baseline of you prostate condition. See what your PSA number is and then see what your doctor says. Fran

Posts.Title: PSA results in

Posts.Content: My surgery was two hours and forty five minutes. My wife also went home and got a splendid call from an operating room nurse about the time they were closing me up saying all went well and how long from then it would be until she could see me. Our hospital was also only 10 minutes away. By the way, unless something bad happens, he would have no issue with oxygen. He will be intibated for the surgery, which means he will have oxygen pumped directly to his lungs through a tube down his throat. Afterwards, he will not even know it happened save for a raspy throat possibly. Fran

Posts.Title: My First PSA Test After Da Vinci Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: In my case, my urologist used the DRE as the trigger for scheduling a biopsy. I trusted his judgement and although it took three to find my cancer, I consider it the reason my G7 cancer was found early and after surgery, I am cancer free. (Hoping to stay that way). Although PSA is also an obvious trigger for a biopsy, in my case Avodart was doing a good job at keeping my PSA low (2.9 at surgery). As has been said many times, every case is different so knowledge and trust in your doctor are certainly key factors in your decision. Good luck. Fran

Posts.Title: Catheter removal. Excited and worried

Posts.Content: Very sorry to hear of your situation. I would surmise that his leaking has a direct correlation to his mental condition, I found that I had to work at it for many months (Kegals, etc.) before I got to the point now where I am hardly leaking at all. If he doesn't care about his urine issues, he obviously does not and hasn't been working at these issues. My suggestion would be to get the clamp. Early on, I thought that would be an easy solution to my leaking dilema as it took little pressure on my penis to make it to the bathroom and keep from leaking. My 85 yr old mother suffers from severe dementia now and is confined to a wheel chair in a nursing home. The long term prognosis for your husband is not good. Good luck and I hope it gets easier for you! Fran

Posts.Title: Question for the wives and one for the men re incontinence.

Posts.Content: Congratulations on catheter removal. Another milestone checked off. I found that while in bed leakage was far less than standing and sitting. When I got up in the middle of the night, I would actually have to squeeze my penis to keep from leaking as I hustled to the bathroom. Don't worry as control comes back slowly but surely! Today after 7 months post op, I wear a light pad during the day for that occasional leak from sneezing or coughing and pad free at night. Keep doing those Kegels! Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Side Effects Short and Long Term of Salvage Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: I am no doctor, but it seems to me that you should have been having PSA tests for many years. The bad news is there is a high probability you have pc. The good news is the scans seem to indicate that it has not spread outside the prostate. Your upcoming biopsy will likely get to the bottom of your extreme PSA...here's hoping if it is Cancer, that it is a low Gleason grade. No matter what you will have treatment options. If I were you I would start your research...does not hurt to be well informed. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Post Op - Two Weeks

Posts.Content: My surgery was two hours and forty five minutes. My wife also went home and got a splendid call from an operating room nurse about the time they were closing me up saying all went well and how long from then it would be until she could see me. Our hospital was also only 10 minutes away. By the way, unless something bad happens, he would have no issue with oxygen. He will be intibated for the surgery, which means he will have oxygen pumped directly to his lungs through a tube down his throat. Afterwards, he will not even know it happened save for a raspy throat possibly. Fran

Posts.Title: Side Effects Short and Long Term of Salvage Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, Gearloose. Sorry to hear of your story, but I am glad you told it. There are many here who find themselves in the same predicament you were in with Gleason 6 cancer diagnosed and not knowing whether AS is a good option for them. Unfortunately, everyone's cancer is different so it is such a roll of the dice to not treat. I was lucky enough (if you can call it lucky) to have G7 cancer which made my choice a lot easier. I had been on Avodart for years and it had shrunk my prostate too, but my urologist was sharp enough to continue to biopsy looking for PCa even though my PSA was 2.9. We found it on the third try and was lucky enough to find it early. Out it came and hopefully I remain cancer free. Good luck with your continued treatment and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Other than being 62 our stories are identical! I am seeing minute progress particularly at night. I am getting a slight urge that my bladder is full three to four times during the night and if hold my penis, I can make it to the toilet and empty my bladder. Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: The only real issue I had was the tape I got from the hospital to attach the tube to my leg was junk. I have a few nurses in my rather large family and they hooked me up with every conceivable tape/velcro thing available. After a little trial and error I found the perfect attachment that worked great and eliminated a lot of plumbing problems. Make sure you ask for and use ointment on the tip of your little buddy and you won't have any issue there! I used the overnight bag almost exclusively because the leg bag is more trouble than it's worth. Good luck with your surgery and we all look forward to hearing from you on the other side. Fran

Posts.Title: The Mental Part

Posts.Content: Your plan seems reasonable. You have to wait 6 weeks from biopsy before surgery anyway. September would be 5 months + . That would give you plenty of time to prepare yourself both mentally and physically for the ordeal. If at all possible, I would try to pick a surgeon and get a date for surgery, so you don't have to wait once you get up north. There are too many G6's that are upgraded after surgery. At 59, you have many years ahead of you. In my mind, you are making the right decision. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: Welcome, Qwei, you have come to great place for insight and advice. Many will weigh in on your condition. It seems to me that infection has been ruled out as a cause of your abnormally high PSA numbers. The fluctuations from month to month can be possibly caused by anything you may have done to aggravate your prostate including sex or bicycling or any number of things prior to your blood draw. In any case your doctor is right in suggesting a biopsy to determine if any cancer exists. I would not hesitate further in having the procedure. There is very little pain and discomfort involved and the results are critical in determining your next move. PCa found early gives you the most options for treatment and the best chance at a cure. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: 9 months.....

Posts.Content: Not a silly question by any stretch! In my case at 62, I still am as active as I've ever been. About to get back to my one hard hour at the gym five days a week. I have been an extremely active volunteer firefighter for 31 years and can' t wait for the doctor to clear me to get back at it! I usually run circles around guys half my age. This cancer thing is just a little bump in the road and I refuse to let it slow me down! I intend on being one of those guys who goes out kickin' and screaming yelling "what a ride!": Fran

Posts.Title: Seminal Vesicle Invasion

Posts.Content: Welcome RTS. I think you and and your urologist are right in leaning towards surgery to remove your cancer. At your age you stand a great chance of being cured and are young enough to tolerate the surgery with little difficulty. I am 4 months post daVinci and expect to get my second undetectable PSA in a couple of weeks. I am back to normal with mild incontinence and ED issues I hope improve as time moves on. Many will chime in with questions to ask your surgeon but experience is probably the key one. Most would say close to one thousand surgeries experience or more would be good. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Constipation getting worse after DaVinci

Posts.Content: Welcome boeinguy! You have come to a great place for insight and advice. It looks like you are a good candidate for active surveillance, what we call AS around here. The key is to watch it closely enough so that you catch it and treat it in time to prevent any cancer from spreading outside the prostate. The good news is Gleason 6 cancer is considered very slow growing and much less aggressive than the G7's,8's and 9's. So that means it could be some years before treatment is warranted, if at all. It should be noted, however, that even with 2-12 core biopsies, cancer could still have been missed. My G7 was found in one of 14 cores on one side but final pathology showed it on both sides. Others will chime in with their take on your situation. In the mean time, read some of the threads on this site to get an idea of the different pca situations that we are all dealing with. In addition, get a copy of Dr. Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. If you have questions, fire away as there are many here who would be happy to help. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: What criteria define's prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club. You have many friends here who have and are struggling with different issues just like you. You will get great insight and help here. I am over 9 weeks post daVinci and still struggling with incontinence but it is much better than where you are now. I was extremely frustrated at three weeks post surgery but that frustration wains as time goes on. You get a little better and a little used to it. I have serious ED so in that regard you are ahead of me! Everyone heals and recovers differently. All I can say is keep doing those Kegels and try to be patient. I find now that if I sit for a long period and overfill my bladder, I have to Kegel all the way to the John to make it without filling my pad. I am down to two pads during the day and one overnight that stays pretty dry. The more active I am, the less control I have but better as the weeks go on. As far as your signature goes, go to your profile page , click on forum actions at top and click on edit profile, and look for edit signature over in the left column. If you click on that it will allow you to enter info that will show up on all your posts. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Husband's biopsy done yesterday

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club Kargok9. Highlander and Otago bring up some good points. The decision on treatment is different for everyone as every single case is different. It has so much to do with age, physical condition, Gleason score, psa, life expectancy, DRE findings, prior urinary and ED issues, and on and on. You have to analyze all these, make a decision and don't look back. In your case, I don't think I would stay on AS for long. Both surgery and Brachy are good options for you. I would decide on one and hopefully put this pca thing behind you so can continue doing what you love for many years to come. Good luck and stay positive. Fran P.S.- I am curious to know if you would be following this same course if you had a confirmed G7 pc??

Posts.Title: 3 weeks after DaVinci... So many questions

Posts.Content: Andy, please believe what you are experiencing is completely normal. That was me three to four weeks post surgery and I had my catheter in for 12 days! As time goes on, you will notice small dribbles during activity and the majority of your urine will stay in your bladder without Kegeling. If you sit for a long period, you will accumulate more urine and pressure than your weak muscle can handle and you will find Kegeling all the way to the bathroom will work. That is my experience now and I am seeing a little improvement in that as the days go by. I experienced the same frustration that you are now. Don't let it get you down. You will dramatically improve. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: New first times.....plus not so good news abou this knee

Posts.Content: Welcome. Sorry your dad is joining. I am guessing you got the numbers backwards PSA of 4.2 and Gleason score of 6. I am surprised at treatment so soon, if in fact he was just diagnosed. In addition Gleason 6 cancer is not considered aggressive so that is good and PSA of 4.2 is only barely marginally high. I would suggest getting a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate Cancer, which many consider one of the bibles on the subject. If everything is as you have described, your dad has a good chance his treatment will be successful. Try not to worry and keep us informed. Good luck, Fran

Posts.Title: 3 weeks after DaVinci... So many questions

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum. Yes, there is a good chance it is nothing serious at this time. I had three biopsies over 4 years driven by rising PSA and DRE results and it wasn't until the third that a small amount of cancer was found. I had been troubled by BPH for some years before that. You are wise, with your family history, to stay on top of your Prostate health. Try not to worry too much and know that you are doing everything that you possibly can and if you end up with a pc diagnosis at some point, it will be early enough that a cure will certainly be attainable. Fran

Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club, Powderfinger. Sorry you had to join. You have come to a very good place for knowledge, insight, and support, as you can tell by the posts above. I was lucky enough to stumble on this site while researching my pc and learned a tremendous amount here. It no doubt made my journey through surgery and recovery far easier. I am just over three months post surgery now and have recovered pretty much true to the norm spelled out in many posts here. Incontinence is still an issue but better as every week goes by and ED is still a major issue. Like Highlander, I had ED from BPH issues before surgery, so I am somewhat used to dealing with that. I am hoping that I get back to where I was before surgery but I fully understand that could take up to a year or more. The most important thing to me is being cancer free and I can deal with everything else. Good luck in your research. You will find that everyone's cancer is different and no one else is just like yours. That makes finding the treatment that works for you just that much harder. Once you decide, go for it and don't look back...no regrets! Stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New member, just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our little club. My take is pick a treatment option and get to it. Steve Jobs ( founder of Apple) tried alternative therapies for his cancer, and I have to think he would be alive today if he had agressively treated it when first diagnosed! If it is indeed confined, you have a great chance of having many happy years in front of you. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your dad has joined our club but you and he will benefit from this site. Read up on the stickies and older posts and you might get a sense of what your dad and his family are in for. Hopefully they have caught this early and with the correct treatment he will become cancer free. It would benefit you both to pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer". It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Stay tuned as many more will chime in with advice and words of encouragement. Good luck and stay positive. You will have your dad around for many years to come. Fran

Posts.Title: prostate riddles

Posts.Content: The PSA is only one of the tools used to help evaluate for PC. The DRE is is a very important one. And the biopsy, of course, is more important still. All, however, have their limitations and drawbacks. It is the judgement and skill of the urologist to evaluate all these to determine what is actually going that is key. All cases are different, so it is hard to put yours or anyone's in with others that are exactly the same...there are none. In my case, my urologist used the changing DRE over a number of years to schedule three biopsies, the third one finding G7 cancer. Because he was paying attention, we found it early enough and after daVinci surgery I am, and hope to remain, cancer free. I say, find a urologist you trust and are comfortable with. Research PC and how it relates to your situation. Eventually, if necessary, chose a course of treatment and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate Questions

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum. Yes, there is a good chance it is nothing serious at this time. I had three biopsies over 4 years driven by rising PSA and DRE results and it wasn't until the third that a small amount of cancer was found. I had been troubled by BPH for some years before that. You are wise, with your family history, to stay on top of your Prostate health. Try not to worry too much and know that you are doing everything that you possibly can and if you end up with a pc diagnosis at some point, it will be early enough that a cure will certainly be attainable. Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome Dan. Sorry you've joined our little club. I was like you, get that sucker out of there! I had the daVinci and am very happy with the results. If you have the means, there are many here who would suggest you search out the best urologist to do your surgery, even if it means traveling to John Hopkins or a similar center of excellence. One that has thousands of surgeries under his belt. I chose my local urologist for a number of reasons. Close to home and family (10 minutes), I trusted his expertise and he had 800 + surgeries behind him, and recommendations from friends that also had them treat their cancer. You have to decide all the factors that are important to YOU. Very personal decision, in what, where, and how! Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New guy...dazed and confused

Posts.Content: The indicator that my uro used to describe the correct Kegel procedure was the top base of the penis. Look for it( and the penis itself) to move into your abdomin as you contract your muscles. You should see it move in 1/4" or more. Stopping your flow while peeing (multiple times if possible) is perfect practice and look for that contraction of your skin just above your penis base while your doing it.

Posts.Title: Update after my surgery

Posts.Content: All giving great advice. I would add that your husband's bottom will be sore for some days. Most find that sitting in a reclined position, whether in the car or at home takes pressure off this area and is much more comfortable. I found the catheter to be the biggest challenge of the whole ordeal. Tough to get comfortable for sleeping but he will get used to it. I was lucky enough to have mine in for 12 days and found the leg bag not worth the trouble and stuck with the large bag for the majority of that time. First bowel movement, first shower, and catheter removal are big milestones that were like religious experiences for me. After that, the slow healing process. Tell him to not get frustrated, it is a long haul. Good luck and stay positive. Two years now since my surgery and it's like it never happened! Fran

Posts.Title: What to expect? Tips?

Posts.Content: Fairwind, he states near the end of the first paragraph that he just made 50. My two cents is, put less stock in the psa number (mine was 2.9 at surgery) and more stock in the biopsy and other scans. You obviously have a tumor that is growing. I would seek treatment as soon as possible. Of course mine was gleason 7 but either way, it is not getting better without some form of treatment and at 50, you have a lot of good years left if treated successfully. That's my take. Others may disagree. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: By The Numbers

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry about your husband joining our pc club. His is a great example of the vagaries of pc...high PSA scores and low Gleason Cancer to low PSA scores and high Gleason disease and everything in between. Your surgeon will probably take both the Prostate and the nerve bundle on that left side and hopefully get it all. He will watch your husbands PSA after surgery for any appreciable rise and you will have salvage radiation as a course of action if necessary. Good luck and stay positive. Fran p.s.- I am surprised Chuck didn't mention getting a copy of "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh (available on Kindle). It is considered one of the bibles on the subject.

Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis - Gleason score 9

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club, Kiwibro. How old are you? Age is a significant stat in deciding what may be the best treatment for you. It just makes sense that someone 70 wouldn't necessarily being leaning towards certain treatment options as someone 40. I would only add that your health should be your number one goal and not work. No one ever says that the guy in the casket should have worked more in his life. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Tbl-12

Posts.Content: We welcome you and your husband to the other side. Prato and Highlander gave you great advice. For the time being I would concentrate on the next six to eight weeks of healing and then see where his psa stands. As Prato said, there is life after daVinci surgery but the healing process is not linear and can be frustrating at times. Although I too was playing golf at 8 weeks post surgery, I was soaking a pad after 9 holes. It took me a year to the day to throw them out and go pad free. Now it's like it never happened! Good luck and hang in there and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis - Gleason score 9

Posts.Content: If he does have an FAA first class medical, I think he will find he is grounded until he pays a visit to his flight physical doctor and gets cleared to fly by him. If I am not mistaken, that includes a PSA test result of zero. I am a recreational pilot and had my surgery at the time my medical ran out. I have not scheduled my next physical but have read that a zero PSA is a requisite. In any case, two weeks from surgery is too ambitious, if you ask me. I considered myself in excellent shape and it took me three plus weeks and even then, it was only half days for a week or so. Tell him, good luck. Fran

Posts.Title: DaVinci 6/25/2013

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club, Allen! Sorry you had to join. Your case is quite similar to mine including owning our own businesses and many work hours per week. You are lucky or unlucky, depending on how you look at it, to have G6 cancer. My G7 made my decision for treatment far easier! I am here to tell you, though, that if you decide on surgery, you will be back to work in virtually no time. I went back to work 1/2 days after 3 weeks and was back full time at about 5. The surgery kicks the stuffing out of you, no question, but you will recover. I am 1 1/2 years post daVinci now and it's almost like it never happened. No decision you make will be wrong, as no matter what you decide, it is right for you! Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: You will have to develop some patience as this is going to be a long process. You will find yourself doing Kegels every time you move from one position to another to avoid that leaking feeling. It will become more natural as time goes on. I am 7 weeks post surgery and while playing golf today, I could not stop leaking while swinging no matter how hard I tried to Kegel. I am using about 3 pads per day while reasonably active and more during heavy activity like today. Be patient and it will get better. Fran

Posts.Title: 9 days post-op

Posts.Content: Bees wife and Aloysius and Let's do this...it is a slow, slow, recovery process that can be very frustrating. The trouble is that in a relatively short time the healing is complete but the continence and ED lags far behind. It is just a matter of getting used to the new normal...like never passing up a bathroom. Always having a spare pad for the just in case. etc., etc. What helped me was staying busy and not dwelling on the issues. So what if I soaked a pad after 9 holes of golf...I knew it would get better and it did but I continued to play as often as I could. Hang in the there, it does get better. Fran

Posts.Title: 9 days post-op

Posts.Content: I had my catheter in for 12 days and it is by far the worst part of the healing process. Someone on the site recommended asking for a prescription for a numbing cream to use on the tip of the penis before I was discharged and I made sure I got it and I feel that helped immensely! I also found that the attachment of the tube to the thigh was critical for comfort. A relative who is a nurse hooked me up with a velcro device that is specially made for this and it also helped position the tube perfectly and keep it there during movement and allowed quick disconnect for bag emptying and cleaning. Tell him to hang in there and the catheter will be out before he knows it and he will be on his way to a full recovery. Most on here will tell you that soon he will find it's almost like it never happened. Good luck, Fran

Posts.Title: Stage IV with Pelvic Lymph Node and Kidney blockage involvement - Survival?

Posts.Content: I am guessing they don't want to remove his prostate because there is a possibility that the cancer has escaped his prostate and he would go through the side effects of surgery for little benefit. Radiation has a good chance of killing the cancer cells both in and outside the prostate and is the preferred treatment in his case. Others will chime in with potential side effects. If you can, pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject and may shed some insight into what your father faces. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Age 73, PSA 10, Gleason 8

Posts.Content: Thanks for the update. I am almost 5 years post surgery and cancer free. My early recovery very much mirrored yours. After 5 years, I still get a urine spot smaller than a dime when active. If I know I am going to active like golfing, I wear a small pad but that is about the only time. I, unfortunately, waited more than 2 years before asking my doctor for injection therapy. You are smart to start now. Don't worry about the needle, it's a piece of cake! LOL Good luck! Fran

Posts.Title: Meeting Mr Da vinci Friday

Posts.Content: Sorry you are joining the club, but welcome. Consider yourself lucky that your PC has been found early which gives you options on a treatment and a better chance of beating the cancer. Dr. Walsh's book is an invaluable resource. This forum is also a great resource and really helped me immensely in my battle. There are some amazingly educated people here who will give you a wealth of both knowledge and experience. You will not travel this road alone! If you learn anything, it will be that every person is different....no two the same...but many similarities exist that will help guide you in your quest to beat PC. Stay positive and keep giving your details...you will get an amazing amount of help in return . Fran

Posts.Title: Meeting Mr Da vinci Friday

Posts.Content: As Bill suggests, I think a lot depends on your individual fitness level. In any case, though, I don't think any of us understand how much it really takes out of us. You tend to feel much better pretty quickly and your mind says you are in better shape than you really are. I went back to work 1/2 days at about three and a half weeks and when I got home at lunch I had to take a pretty good nap! It took me two or three weeks of that before I was able to go full time and then it was off to bed after dinner. It was months, not weeks, until I felt back to my pre surgery stamina. Take it slow and easy and listen to your body closely! Fran

Posts.Content: Bob, what you are experiencing, I suspect, is pretty normal. Talk yourself into slowing down and give your body time to recuperate. Your mind is telling you that you feel good and it's time to get back to normal. Your body, however, is still a LONG way from full recovery. It took me a full three months to where my body was truly 99% back to pre-op condition and I considered myself to be in pretty good condition. Fran

Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your joining our club, Chief. You have come to a great place for information and support. Like NJS said, the troops here need as much information as you can provide to accurately weigh in on your situation. The direction you take with treatment is directly connected to your age, your physical condition and how advanced your disease is. Definitely get Dr, Walsh's book as it is considered on of the bibles on the subject. Also read a lot of the back posts of many of us here and you will get some insight into what you are in for and up against. You will find that no two pc cases are the same, and the treatment that works for one may not be right for another with very similar diagnosis. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Path report is in, not good numbers

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your joining our club, Chief. You have come to a great place for information and support. Like NJS said, the troops here need as much information as you can provide to accurately weigh in on your situation. The direction you take with treatment is directly connected to your age, your physical condition and how advanced your disease is. Definitely get Dr, Walsh's book as it is considered on of the bibles on the subject. Also read a lot of the back posts of many of us here and you will get some insight into what you are in for and up against. You will find that no two pc cases are the same, and the treatment that works for one may not be right for another with very similar diagnosis. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Do kegels after surgery increase the likelyhood of leakage

Posts.Content: Welcome to our site and here's hoping you don't get to join our little club! We have all been through what you are going through. You are wise to be vigilant with your PSA and I would have done the biopsy as well. It's the only way so far to know definitively whether you have pc or not and if you do, how aggressive it may be. As you research you will come to know that no two cases of pc are alike. In addition cases can range from high PSA with low Gleason score cancer to high PSA cases with low G scores and everything in between. Besides urinary issues, do you suffer from ED issues as well? Many of us with enlarged prostates were struggling with ED prior to surgery and that continues after treatment. Those with smaller prostate's that had less ED issues seem to have a better outcome with sexual function after surgery. Good luck and stay positive no matter what. Be sure to let us know how you make out. Fran

Posts.Title: Do kegels after surgery increase the likelyhood of leakage

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, Leo. Sorry you have to be here but you have come to a good place. You will get great insight and feedback here. You are right that sex or anything else that tweaks your prostate will affect the psa number. How much is another question but either way the amount of increase against the amount of time between tests is a bigger marker. I would not hesitate in getting the biopsy done and see where you stand asap. There is very little chance of infection and early detection is key. You will find through your research that no two pca cases are the same. Low psa cases can have lots of cancer and high psa cases can have none. It took a third biopsy over 5 years in my case to find mine and my psa was 2.9 at diagnosis. I chose surgery because I was convinced we found it early and as of now, consider myself cancer free. I am hoping that continues as I have my psa tested for the next 5 years. Others will chime here with more advice but I expect most will say have that biopsy. Good luck. Fran

Posts.Title: 2 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome to our little club. You have come to a great place for insight and advice. There is never only one option. Much depends on your age, physical health, mindset and many other factors. As you can see in my signature, I was 62 when diagnosed with a PSA of 2.9 but ended up with G7 in both lobes after surgical pathology. I am hoping because of early detection, we got it all out and I will remain cancer free. We'll see. Read a bunch of the threads on this forum for a wealth of info. Also pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer as it is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Stay tuned as many more will weigh in. Give us your age and as many of your stats and history as you can. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Husband with Gleason 9 at age 48

Posts.Content: Interesting Bill! The obvious question, I suppose, is because the Gleason score can routinely be higher in post surgery pathology, could the Gleason 6 originally diagnosed really have been a 7? In my case, the initial biopsy showed one side involved but the final pathology showed both sides with cancer. I had initially decided to probably wait till this fall to have the surgery, but my urologist convinced me to act more quickly and take advantage of the early stage of my cancer. I am glad he did. In addition, the psa score seems to be the real monkey wrench in all of this. I am still baffled that mine at surgery was only 2.9. Good luck with your Kegels! Fran

Posts.Title: Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Interesting Bill! The obvious question, I suppose, is because the Gleason score can routinely be higher in post surgery pathology, could the Gleason 6 originally diagnosed really have been a 7? In my case, the initial biopsy showed one side involved but the final pathology showed both sides with cancer. I had initially decided to probably wait till this fall to have the surgery, but my urologist convinced me to act more quickly and take advantage of the early stage of my cancer. I am glad he did. In addition, the psa score seems to be the real monkey wrench in all of this. I am still baffled that mine at surgery was only 2.9. Good luck with your Kegels! Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome Bob. Sorry you have to join our little club. You will get great insight and advice here. I don't think there is a person here who hasn't benefited from being here because we all are in the same boat! However, everyone's pca is a little different. That's what makes it hard to recommend a treatment option for anyone as no two are the same. What worked for me doesn't necessarily work for you. And that is emotionally as well as physically. Give the troops here as much information as you can on your test results and history and you will get some great feedback. Also pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New guy...

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you are having bowel control problems. My issue is urine control. Very minute improvements daily. Nighttime fairly dry but getting up every 2-3 hours to empty my bladder. Great stream but small to medium volume. Moving during the day very little control. Sitting during the day, I seem to hold urine and if I "Kegel" all the way to the bathroom, I can empty my bladder before leaking. Any activity, uncontrollable leaking. A little more control every day, so I am being patient, doing Kegels, and hoping for continued improvement . Fran

Posts.Title: Day 22, post-operative robotic prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Knowledge, although confusing at times, is power, Joe. Your stats say that 2 put of 100 will be severely affected by PC. The big question is are you willing to take the chance of being one of those two! There is a saying on this forum that NO two cases of PC are exactly the same, so you cannot look for the one that is like your case and do what he did! Some, like myself, had an easier time at making a treatment decision because the stats were weighted in the treatment direction, like my having a G7 diagnosis. Not sure what I would have decided had it been G6. In any case, do your research, decide what you are going to do, and go for it and don't look back. What ever you decide, it will be right for YOU! Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Welcome me to the club!

Posts.Content: Dennis, relax and take a breath! The PSA is just a number. In my case it was artificially low because I was on a drug to shrink my prostate due to BPH, which caused me weak urine stream and other problem and some ED issues. My urologist caught my cancer early, by paying attention to subtle differences in the feel of my prostate over 5 years and biopsies that finally found some cancer on the third biopsy. It takes those three tests to confirm any cancer. As to your question about symptoms, there are significant ones for BPH that don't necessarily mean any cancer and there can be cancer with absolutely no symptoms. No two prostate cancer victims have exactly the same disease. There is no exact duplicate of your issue that you can find to study and copy. Just continue to research, ask questions and test and search out the best answer for you. There are many ,many threads on this forum you can read for initial guidance. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Dennis, relax and take a breath! The PSA is just a number. In my case it was artificially low because I was on a drug to shrink my prostate due to BPH, which caused me weak urine stream and other problem and some ED issues. My urologist caught my cancer early, by paying attention to subtle differences in the feel of my prostate over 5 years and biopsies that finally found some cancer on the third biopsy. It takes those three tests to confirm any cancer. As to your question about symptoms, there are significant ones for BPH that don't necessarily mean any cancer and there can be cancer with absolutely no symptoms. No two prostate cancer victims have exactly the same disease. There is no exact duplicate of your issue that you can find to study and copy. Just continue to research, ask questions and test and search out the best answer for you. There are many ,many threads on this forum you can read for initial guidance. Good luck and stay positive. Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome Brian, sorry you are joining our club. You have come to a great place for information and advice. One of the books you get should be Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. You will find as you research and read the stories here, that no two pca cases are the same. You cannot look for the case that is just like yours and do what they did...it does not exist. You will have to research as best you can, find a doctor you trust, decide on a treatment plan and go for it, confident in your decision. If you have questions, fire away, as there are many on this forum that are eager to help with a wealth of knowledge. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Welcome to the site wishful! You have come to a great place for information and insight. To begin, don't get too nervous about your 4.9 PSA ...it does not suggest you have prostate cancer in and of itself. High normal for a person of your age is 4.0. A DRE is certainly next up so your urologist can determine if there is anything abnormal about the size and shape of your prostate. Depending what that shows, he may suggest a biopsy to look for any cancerous tumors. The biopsy, though uncomfortable is relatively painless. A DRE can stimulate your prostate to artificially inflate your PSA some, so make sure the blood draw happens prior to the DRE. I would not worry too much, until a biopsy confirms any cancer you might have and even then, there is a chance that it may be low grade giving you many options including watchful waiting (active surveillance ) to see how it progresses. Many on the forum will chime in so stay tuned. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Content: NJS has given you excellent research information, September. Unfortunately even the research does not answer the question whether to treat before recurrence or wait and treat after. Sounds like your urologist favors the treat first protocol. You and your husband will ultimately have to make that decision. That's a tough one and I don't know what I would do. Concentrate on recovery now. In a few weeks he'll feel almost back to normal and you can then start to consider your options. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Content: Like you Jim, I found the leg bag far more trouble than it was worth. I tried it once and that was enough for me and stuck with the large bag exclusively. I was lucky enough to have my catheter for 12 days (sic)! As I have said here many times, it was by far the worst part of the whole process. Once you get the catheter out, Massbirdies, you will be able to get back to being a normal person again. It will take a while with leakage and all, but hang in there. It does get better! Fran

Posts.Title: Post Op Rant

Posts.Content: My doctor told me it took months for the stitches to dissolve. You had major plumbing reconstruction during major surgery even though you only have 5 or 6 small scares to show for it. It is easy to think that you are more healed than you really are. For the majority of RALP victims, it takes months to get to a point where you have decent urine control. My experience is that the urge to urinate has also been redirected and you have to learn what the new urge feels like. I still wake up in the middle of the night on occasion not realizing why until it dawns on me my body is telling me it's time to pee. It was almost a year to the day that I was able to throw the small shields in the trash and considered myself fully continent. Be patient and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Dennis, relax and take a breath! The PSA is just a number. In my case it was artificially low because I was on a drug to shrink my prostate due to BPH, which caused me weak urine stream and other problem and some ED issues. My urologist caught my cancer early, by paying attention to subtle differences in the feel of my prostate over 5 years and biopsies that finally found some cancer on the third biopsy. It takes those three tests to confirm any cancer. As to your question about symptoms, there are significant ones for BPH that don't necessarily mean any cancer and there can be cancer with absolutely no symptoms. No two prostate cancer victims have exactly the same disease. There is no exact duplicate of your issue that you can find to study and copy. Just continue to research, ask questions and test and search out the best answer for you. There are many ,many threads on this forum you can read for initial guidance. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome to the site wishful! You have come to a great place for information and insight. To begin, don't get too nervous about your 4.9 PSA ...it does not suggest you have prostate cancer in and of itself. High normal for a person of your age is 4.0. A DRE is certainly next up so your urologist can determine if there is anything abnormal about the size and shape of your prostate. Depending what that shows, he may suggest a biopsy to look for any cancerous tumors. The biopsy, though uncomfortable is relatively painless. A DRE can stimulate your prostate to artificially inflate your PSA some, so make sure the blood draw happens prior to the DRE. I would not worry too much, until a biopsy confirms any cancer you might have and even then, there is a chance that it may be low grade giving you many options including watchful waiting (active surveillance ) to see how it progresses. Many on the forum will chime in so stay tuned. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Title: 6 week meeting with surgeon on Thursday

Posts.Content: Welcome cmcona, sorry to hear you are joining our club. To the question of considering surgery, I would recommend that you find a surgeon you trust and go for it. There are many stories here of men who chose to wait and found out later that more aggressive cancer was missed on biopsy and/or it had spread outside the prostate putting them in a worse predicament. Like my case, I would take advantage of finding it early and have it removed. You are young enough that you should recover nicely and have many more cancer free years with your grandkids. I was lucky enough that my urologist was paying attention, found my cancer early and is also an excellent surgeon with 1000+ daVinci's behind him. I am a member of the Zero Club (no detectable psa) and expect to remain a member and three months post surgery, I am as active as I was before with minor incontinence that is still improving every week. If you had BPH for 10 years you probably experienced some ED issues during that time like I did. I am hoping that I get back to the level of function I had before surgery or better, but that takes the longest so I will just have to wait and see. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: I was on the Imipramine for a while too, Jtown! I can't tell you that it helped or not. It is a long, slow healing process. It is easy to get frustrated because your mind expects you to be farther along. Besides some small, extra belly buttons, it's hard to tell that you have had major plumbing reconstruction. It was almost a year to the day that I was able to stop using any shields at all. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Not me

Posts.Content: I was 62 1/2 when my G7 cancer was found. I only had 2 of 14 cores cancerous and on one side but I opted for daVinci surgery and now, 2 1/2 years later, it's almost like it never happened. Final pathology confirmed the G7 but it was found in both lobes. IMHO, your situation demands treatment. Do your research, decide which treatment is best for you and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive. Fran
