Posts.Title: Reluctant new member questions, including second opinion on biopsy and stage of PC

Posts.Content: Just passed the 3 yr anniversary of my DaVinci surgery. Figured I would let those new to the game know that things are still A-OK after 3 years. Incontinence is not an issue and there doesn't seem to be any change in that regard as I get older, soon to be 66. I continue to struggle with ED but had serious issues before surgery, so wasn't expecting any great change for the better in that regard anyway. Aside from that I remain very active and tell everyone it's almost like it never happened. So, those of you just starting your recovery or about to have surgery, I am here to tell you there is life after prostate cancer surgery. Hang in there. Fran

Posts.Title: Kegel Question

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. Very sorry you had to join! You will get excellent advice and support here. You will learn quickly that no two prostate cancers are the same. That makes it difficult to follow any prescribed path because what is good for me may not be the best treatment for you. In my case, finding G 7 cancer early enough, the obvious choice for me was surgery. AS was off the table, and I wanted to take advantage of finding it early, and believed surgery would most probably rid me of cancer. The jury will be out for a while but it looks good so far. It would be prudent to get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostrate Cancer. It is consider the bible on the subject. Others here will chime in with their take on your situation. Good luck and keep us informed. Fran

Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: If there is any chance that it is still organ confined, I would guess your urologist will suggest surgery. Surgery is delayed until 6-8 weeks after a biopsy to allow the prostate to heal. If you go that route, make sure your surgeon has quite a few hundred surgeries to his credit. As our administrator Chuck likes to say, you only get one shot at this so make it a good one! Stay positive and let us know how your consult goes on the 20th. Fran

Posts.Title: 6 months and Mexico

Posts.Content: Welcome, Gideon. Hope your not joining, but if you are, you will find great insight from this group. I was in your shoes in my 50's and it took me three biopsies over 6 years to finally confirm pca. Because my urologist and I were paying close attention, we are convinced we found it early and after surgery I am and will remain cancer free (at least prostate cancer!). Finding and treating it early is a huge plus depending on how aggressive it is. You might get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Good luck and let us know how you make out. Fran

Posts.Title: The VA

Posts.Content: Welcome vaom8! Sorry you had to join our little club. If you can, give us your age and where you live. Also, the date of your surgery. As far as surgery, be prepared to be catheterized for 7-10 days or more. For some of us who had the robotic surgery, that was the toughest to get used to. To prepare for that, loose fitting sweat pants or the like would be good for your trip home from the hospital and at home while dealing with your urine bag. Most here would tell you to use the large bag almost exclusively as the small leg bag is more a hassle than it is worth. I would expect that you will have trouble getting in and out of a chair or bed for the first week and stairs will be difficult. Slow and easy was always our mantra as the healing process begins. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer & surgery @ 39 years

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. Very sorry you had to join! You will get excellent advice and support here. You will learn quickly that no two prostate cancers are the same. That makes it difficult to follow any prescribed path because what is good for me may not be the best treatment for you. In my case, finding G 7 cancer early enough, the obvious choice for me was surgery. AS was off the table, and I wanted to take advantage of finding it early, and believed surgery would most probably rid me of cancer. The jury will be out for a while but it looks good so far. It would be prudent to get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostrate Cancer. It is consider the bible on the subject. Others here will chime in with their take on your situation. Good luck and keep us informed. Fran

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Everyone is right. Stay calm and read as much as possible. No two pca's are the same. I had G7 with psa of 2.9. I am sure there are examples of very high psa's with little or no cancer and/or low Gleason score disease. I got all worked up after my second biopsy and it ended up negative. In an ironic twist, I was far calmer on the third and found it much easier accepting the positive finding. Go figure! This forum has a wealth of knowledge and insight and helped me immensely! Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: 77 psa

Posts.Content: Interesting Bill! The obvious question, I suppose, is because the Gleason score can routinely be higher in post surgery pathology, could the Gleason 6 originally diagnosed really have been a 7? In my case, the initial biopsy showed one side involved but the final pathology showed both sides with cancer. I had initially decided to probably wait till this fall to have the surgery, but my urologist convinced me to act more quickly and take advantage of the early stage of my cancer. I am glad he did. In addition, the psa score seems to be the real monkey wrench in all of this. I am still baffled that mine at surgery was only 2.9. Good luck with your Kegels! Fran

Posts.Title: Incontinence Exp

Posts.Content: Good read, Carol! Glad that you posted it so others can benefit. I don't think there is anyone, even the lurkers, who haven't benefited from this site. Chuck and others are correct in wondering what your husbands Gleason score was which we all know makes all the difference in the world. My only comment would be that anyone who has researched and read the many tales of PC club members here knows that no two are alike! The disease runs the gammet from low PSA scores with aggressive cancer to high PSA scores and low Gleason score cancer, and everything in between. Some like Chuck and I have severe BPH prior to diagnosis and others with no BPH at all. In the end, what is key is early, accurate diagnosis and selecting a treatment that is good for YOU. And what is good for you might not necessarily be right for the next person with a similar case. There is that mental aspect, that you so eloquently detailed in your blog, which is different for all of us, just like the differences between you and your husband. Keep us posted on his condition. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

I am hoping because of early detection, we got it all out and I will remain cancer free. We'll see. Read a bunch of the threads on this forum for a wealth of info. Also pick up a copy of Dr. Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer as it is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Stay tuned as many more will weigh in. Posts.Title: Incontinence Exp

Posts.Content: Knowledge, although confusing at times, is power, Joe. Your stats say that 2 put of 100 will be severely affected by PC. The big question is are you willing to take the chance of being one of those two! There is a saying on this forum that NO two cases of PC are exactly the same, so you cannot look for the one that is like your case and do what he did! Some, like myself, had an easier time at making a treatment decision because the stats were weighted in the treatment direction, like my having a G7 diagnosis. Not sure what I would have decided had it been G6. In any case, do your research, decide what you are going to do, and go for it and don't look back. What ever you decide, it will be right for YOU! Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Welcome Israel. Sorry to hear of your plight. I was in your same predicament some years ago in my late 50's. Over the course of 6 years I had three biopsies before pca was found. Funny, I was convinced and prepared for a positive finding after the second but it to was negative. When pc was found on the third a couple of years later, I was actually relieved to find it, convinced that we were paying attention and found it really early with only one core of 14 positive. Now after surgery I am and hope to remain cancer free and am pretty happy how everything went, even with some slight incontinence and ED issues still. I hope you don't have and don't get pc but if you do, find it early and treat it aggressively and get on with your life. You should pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: First post-op PSA results

Posts.Content: Welcome to the site wishful! You have come to a great place for information and insight. To begin, don't get too nervous about your 4.9 PSA ...it does not suggest you have prostate cancer in and of itself. High normal for a person of your age is 4.0. A DRE is certainly next up so your urologist can determine if there is anything abnormal about the size and shape of your prostate. Depending what that shows, he may suggest a biopsy to look for any cancerous tumors. The biopsy, though uncomfortable is relatively painless. A DRE can stimulate your prostate to artificially inflate your PSA some, so make sure the blood draw happens prior to the DRE. I would not worry too much, until a biopsy confirms any cancer you might have and even then, there is a chance that it may be low grade giving you many options including watchful waiting (active surveillance ) to see how it progresses. Many on the forum will chime in so stay tuned. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Dennis, relax and take a breath! The PSA is just a number. In my case it was artificially low because I was on a drug to shrink my prostate due to BPH, which caused me weak urine stream and other problem and some ED issues. My urologist caught my cancer early, by paying attention to subtle differences in the feel of my prostate over 5 years and biopsies that finally found some cancer on the third biopsy. It takes those three tests to confirm any cancer. As to your question about symptoms, there are significant ones for BPH that don't necessarily mean any cancer and there can be cancer with absolutely no symptoms. No two prostate cancer victims have exactly the same disease. There is no exact duplicate of your issue that you can find to study and copy. Just continue to research, ask questions and test and search out the best answer for you. There are many ,many threads on this forum you can read for initial guidance. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: T-Minus 36 Hours until da Vinci...

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you are having bowel control problems. My issue is urine control. Very minute improvements daily. Nighttime fairly dry but getting up every 2-3 hours to empty my bladder. Great stream but small to medium volume. Moving during the day very little control. Sitting during the day, I seem to hold urine and if I "Kegel" all the way to the bathroom, I can empty my bladder before leaking. Any activity, uncontrollable leaking. A little more control every day, so I am being patient, doing Kegels, and hoping for continued improvement . Fran

Posts.Title: Thanks for the peace of mind R.L.T.

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club but sorry you were forced to join. Great advice on this site. It helped me immensely. Please note that almost no two cancers are exactly alike so it is hard to put yours into a particular slot for comparison with others. I also was diagnosed at 62 but no history in my family. I have wondered out loud more than once, how I would have done things differently if I was diagnosed G6 instead of G7! I often thought that the G7 made my decision easy, and after daVinci surgery about 18 months ago, I have remained cancer free and other than pretty severe ED which I had from BPH prior to surgery, it is almost like it never happened. My BPH had me under my urologists scrutiny for some years until cancer was found at a third biopsy, so I was lucky enough to find mine early. This gave little chance that my cancer had escaped the prostate and a good chance for a cure. Only future PSA testing will confirm that but I am very confident. Continue to monitor your PSA, DRE's, and if warranted more biopsies and hopefully after much research, you will find a treatment choice that is perfect for you. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: Welcome Brian, sorry you are joining our club. You have come to a great place for information and advice. One of the books you get should be Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. You will find as you research and read the stories here, that no two pca cases are the same. You cannot look for the case that is just like yours and do what they did...it does not exist. You will have to research as best you can, find a doctor you trust, decide on a treatment plan and go for it, confident in your decision. If you have questions, fire away, as there are many on this forum that are eager to help with a wealth of knowledge. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: NJS has given you excellent research information, September. Unfortunately even the research does not answer the question whether to treat before recurrence or wait and treat after. Sounds like your urologist favors the treat first protocol. You and your husband will ultimately have to make that decision. That's a tough one and I don't know what I would do. Concentrate on recovery now. In a few weeks he'll feel almost back to normal and you can then start to consider your options. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club but sorry you were forced to join. Great advice on this site. It helped me immensely. Please note that almost no two cancers are exactly alike so it is hard to put yours into a particular slot for comparison with others. I also was diagnosed at 62 but no history in my family. I have wondered out loud more than once, how I would have done things differently if I was diagnosed G6 instead of G7! I often thought that the G7 made my decision easy, and after daVinci surgery about 18 months ago, I have remained cancer free and other than pretty severe ED which I had from BPH prior to surgery, it is almost like it never happened. My BPH had me under my urologists scrutiny for some years until cancer was found at a third biopsy, so I was lucky enough to find mine early. This gave little chance that my cancer had escaped the prostate and a good chance for a cure. Only future PSA testing will confirm that but I am very confident. Continue to monitor your PSA, DRE's, and if warranted more biopsies and hopefully after much research, you will find a treatment choice that is perfect for you. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New to forum- Have had prostate cancer for just over one year

Posts.Content: My doctor told me it took months for the stitches to dissolve. You had major plumbing reconstruction during major surgery even though you only have 5 or 6 small scares to show for it. It is easy to think that you are more healed than you really are. For the majority of RALP victims, it takes months to get to a point where you have decent urine control. My experience is that the urge to urinate has also been redirected and you have to learn what the new urge feels like. I still wake up in the middle of the night on occasion not realizing why until it dawns on me my body is telling me it's time to pee. It was almost a year to the day that I was able to throw the small shields in the trash and considered myself fully continent. Be patient and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome to the site wishful! You have come to a great place for information and insight. To begin, don't get too nervous about your 4.9 PSA ...it does not suggest you have prostate cancer in and of itself. High normal for a person of your age is 4.0. A DRE is certainly next up so your urologist can determine if there is anything abnormal about the size and shape of your prostate. Depending what that shows, he may suggest a biopsy to look for any cancerous tumors. The biopsy, though uncomfortable is relatively painless. A DRE can stimulate your prostate to artificially inflate your PSA some, so make sure the blood draw happens prior to the DRE. I would not worry too much, until a biopsy confirms any cancer you might have and even then, there is a chance that it may be low grade giving you many options including watchful waiting (active surveillance ) to see how it progresses. Many on the forum will chime in so stay tuned. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Dennis, relax and take a breath! The PSA is just a number. In my case it was artificially low because I was on a drug to shrink my prostate due to BPH, which caused me weak urine stream and other problem and some ED issues. My urologist caught my cancer early, by paying attention to subtle differences in the feel of my prostate over 5 years and biopsies that finally found some cancer on the third biopsy. It takes those three tests to confirm any cancer. As to your question about symptoms, there are significant ones for BPH that don't necessarily mean any cancer and there can be cancer with absolutely no symptoms. No two prostate cancer victims have exactly the same disease. There is no exact duplicate of your issue that you can find to study and copy. Just continue to research, ask questions and test and search out the best answer for you. There are many ,many threads on this forum you can read for initial guidance. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome to the site wishful! You have come to a great place for information and insight. To begin, don't get too nervous about your 4.9 PSA ...it does not suggest you have prostate cancer in and of itself. High normal for a person of your age is 4.0. A DRE is certainly next up so your urologist can determine if there is anything abnormal about the size and shape of your prostate. Depending what that shows, he may suggest a biopsy to look for any cancerous tumors. The biopsy, though uncomfortable is relatively painless. A DRE can stimulate your prostate to artificially inflate your PSA some, so make sure the blood draw happens prior to the DRE. I would not worry too much, until a biopsy confirms any cancer you might have and even then, there is a chance that it may be low grade giving you many options including watchful waiting (active surveillance ) to see how it progresses. Many on the forum will chime in so stay tuned. Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Title: Expain aggressive cancer

Posts.Content: My doctor told me it took months for the stitches to dissolve. You had major plumbing reconstruction during major surgery even though you only have 5 or 6 small scares to show for it. It is easy to think that you are more healed than you really are. For the majority of RALP victims, it takes months to get to a point where you have decent urine control. My experience is that the urge to urinate has also been redirected and you have to learn what the new urge feels like. I still wake up in the middle of the night on occasion not realizing why until it dawns on me my body is telling me it's time to pee. It was almost a year to the day that I was able to throw the small shields in the trash and considered myself fully continent. Be patient and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Simple Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: I had fluctuating psa's and three biopsies over 5 years, the third finding G7 cancer. I continue to think the biopsies found my cancer early enough that surgery has left me cancer free and that was the whole point. In your case, I would not hesitate to have another biopsy and see where you stand. I agree with Fairwind...an MRI and/or CT scan is no substitute for a biopsy. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate Biospys safe?

Posts.Content: I was 62 1/2 when my G7 cancer was found. I only had 2 of 14 cores cancerous and on one side but I opted for daVinci surgery and now, 2 1/2 years later, it's almost like it never happened. Final pathology confirmed the G7 but it was found in both lobes. IMHO, your situation demands treatment. Do your research, decide which treatment is best for you and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Hello drb46. I know where you are coming from with the multiple biopsies. I had three over 5 years and it was the third that found my G7 cancer. Each was triggered by a psa rise or an abnormal DRE and in each case, I concurred with my doctor in having the biopsy. I was lucky enough to find my cancer early and after surgery, with luck, I will remain cancer free. What is your psa and what are your DRE results? By the way, I was treating my BPH with Avodart which did a great job shrinking my prostate and lowering psa (2.9) at diagnosis. Fran

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club, Tom. You have gotten some great advise from some of our distinguished members. I would add that if you decide on a surgeon or facility for surgery, schedule it asap so you will have a slot reserved. You have to wait 6 weeks from biopsy before surgery anyway so might as well line up a spot. You can always cancel if you opt to go another route. Also know that your case is unique. You will not find another just like it so don't waste time looking for the success story to copy. Do your research, choose a treatment and don't look back. Whatever you decide will be right for you! good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Update on Husbands Biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. Very sorry you had to join! You will get excellent advice and support here. You will learn quickly that no two prostate cancers are the same. That makes it difficult to follow any prescribed path because what is good for me may not be the best treatment for you. In my case, finding G 7 cancer early enough, the obvious choice for me was surgery. AS was off the table, and I wanted to take advantage of finding it early, and believed surgery would most probably rid me of cancer. The jury will be out for a while but it looks good so far. It would be prudent to get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostrate Cancer. It is consider the bible on the subject. Others here will chime in with their take on your situation. Good luck and keep us informed. Fran

I can sympathize with those who want to keep this matter private but I for one am not made up that way. Fran

Posts.Title: New Member of the group

Posts.Content: Welcome, Gideon. Hope your not joining, but if you are, you will find great insight from this group. I was in your shoes in my 50's and it took me three biopsies over 6 years to finally confirm pca. Because my urologist and I were paying close attention, we are convinced we found it early and after surgery I am and will remain cancer free (at least prostate cancer!). Finding and treating it early is a huge plus depending on how aggressive it is. You might get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. Good luck and let us know how you make out. Fran

Posts.Title: Newbie, prostate cancer diagnosis after a health fair blood test

Posts.Content: The catheter was the big shock for me and the worst part of the ordeal. My first impression was that they had inserted a 5/8" garden hose up my penis! Getting used to the catheter and urine bag takes some effort. Insist that your nurse get you some Velcro leg attachments for the catheter tube and stick it on your upper thigh. It will minimize the movement of the tube and therefore increase your comfort level. Also insist on some lidocaine cream for the tip of your penis and use it often. Come up with a plan for rolling out of bed and recliners you are in which will minimize the discomfort considerably. Walking as often as you can will help speed your recovery and give you something to do. Forget the leg bag and use the large collection bag almost exclusively. The leg bag is far more trouble than it is worth. Almost everyone adds Metamucil or similar stool softener to their diet to help with your first bowel movement. Good luck Tuesday and we look forward to hearing from you on the other side! Fran

Posts.Title: recooping after surgery

Posts.Content: If there is any chance that it is still organ confined, I would guess your urologist will suggest surgery. Surgery is delayed until 6-8 weeks after a biopsy to allow the prostate to heal. If you go that route, make sure your surgeon has quite a few hundred surgeries to his credit. As our administrator Chuck likes to say, you only get one shot at this so make it a good one! Stay positive and let us know how your consult goes on the 20th. Fran

Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: Howdy. You seem to have a history of yo-yoing PSA. Your 7.3 in 2006 was followed by a 5.0 in the same year and a 4.5 the following. Why not wait 6 months (or even 3) and see if it indeed comes down again. If not then get that biopsy. I had three over some years, and all were driven by DRE findings, not necessarily my PSA. With your enormous prostate, do you have any urinary or ED issues? Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: need help about prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Good luck Hopper! I work in steel construction and although I mostly supervise now, it can be physically demanding as well as volunteer firefighting as my "hobby". LOL Chuck is right on...you should plan on 6 weeks. The operation takes more out of you than you think. You heal on the outside and your mind thinks you are ready to go but the major plumbing reconstruction takes a bit longer. I was back to desk duty at three weeks for 1/2 days and had to take a nap in the afternoons I was so tired. I was back to firefighting and full time no restrictions at 6 weeks. Once the catheter is removed at 1 week +/- you will be well on your way to recovery. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: New Member of the group

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. Very sorry you had to join! You will get excellent advice and support here. You will learn quickly that no two prostate cancers are the same. That makes it difficult to follow any prescribed path because what is good for me may not be the best treatment for you. In my case, finding G 7 cancer early enough, the obvious choice for me was surgery. AS was off the table, and I wanted to take advantage of finding it early, and believed surgery would most probably rid me of cancer. The jury will be out for a while but it looks good so far. It would be prudent to get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostrate Cancer. It is consider the bible on the subject. Others here will chime in with their take on your situation. Good luck and keep us informed. Fran

Posts.Content: Your urologist, I expect, would be analyzing both your PSA and your DRE to come to his conclusion to biopsy. Posts.Title: A note about forums for newbies....

Posts.Content: Hi All, Nice to see Highlander still monitoring the Forum. Keep up the great work you do. Coming up on my 4 year anniversary of DaVinci surgery on July 17th. Haven't posted in quite some time but was brought back having found out a 54 year old cousin just had surgery at Dana Farber in Boston. His initial biopsy pathology was 7 +8's but a re-read by DF had it at 8 +9's with a PSA of 36. I have given him as much advice as I could and suggested he check out this forum and hope he does. I am waiting to see what his final pathology report is and if he had negative margins and no vesicles or lymph nodes involved. Hoping for the best for him. I continue on with yearly PSA tests of 0 with no continence problems but severe ED, which I have pretty much have grown accustomed to. Fran

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and sex drive

Posts.Content: Welcome! Creekrat is right...the DRE is an important tool in your urologist's arsenal. It was THE reason that triggered my three biopsies, finding G7 cancer on the third early enough to, after daVinci, hopefully leave me cancer free. I would get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostrate Cancer, considered one of the bibles on the subject and study up on the disease so you are well versed on the subject after the March biopsy. And we are here to help you fill in the blanks. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Concerned Partner

Posts.Content: I detested the leg bag and used the large bag almost exclusively. Seems to me it was far more trouble than it was worth. I found, and reiterated here often, that the catheter was by far the most difficult issue to deal with in the whole daVinci surgery process (at least for me). My surgeon likes to leave his patients catheters in for two weeks. I considered myself lucky to have been able to have it removed on the 12th day. Good luck...Friday will be here before you know it. Fran

Posts.Title: Post Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery - 3 years later

Posts.Content: Hi Leo, I never had any blood in my stool and really no blood in urine following three biopsies but doctor always warned me of possible blood in urine. I had blood in my ejaculate for about two weeks. Turns it dark brown. I would surmize that the you could have sex at this point and the sooner you clear that old blood from your system the sooner it will be back to normal. It is kind of disconcerting looking, but wife was prepared and ok with it. Good luck and I'm sure you are anxious for the results. Fran

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of the loss of your wife. I guess the answer would lie in what both your surgeon and an oncologist think about your prognosis. Whichever would give you the best chance of a cure would be my choice. You could always hire a visiting nurse or home instead worker to help you through the recovery after surgery, if that is your choice. You would only need someone part time for a week or so, before you could handle it on your own. Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Content: Welcome to our site and sorry your husband had to join our little club. Highlander and the others have pretty much covered everything. I would only had that it is human nature to try and find the perfect example of your husbands pc and do what they did for a successful outcome. Unfortunately, each pc case is uniquely different...no two are exactly the same. You and your husband must do your research, decide on a treatment, and don't look back. There is life after pc! Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

They do exist and I would suggest you find yourself one. Good luck and stay positive, Fran

Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Hi Leo, I never had any blood in my stool and really no blood in urine following three biopsies but doctor always warned me of possible blood in urine. I had blood in my ejaculate for about two weeks. Turns it dark brown. I would surmize that the you could have sex at this point and the sooner you clear that old blood from your system the sooner it will be back to normal. It is kind of disconcerting looking, but wife was prepared and ok with it. Good luck and I'm sure you are anxious for the results. Fran

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Hi Ronny. I had the daVinci and coming up on 5 months post surgery, it's almost like it never happened. I was pleasantly surprised to be able to walk out of the hospital the day after my surgery and would recommend it to anyone. I didn't have the balls before surgery, but after, I watched the surgery on YouTube and in the hands of a skilled surgeon the robot is an amazing tool. Others here are right. Which procedure is less important than who performs it! Find someone that is highly experienced, make your choice and don't look back. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group, although very sorry you and your dad have to be here! There is a wealth of info on this sight and many will be chiming in with insight and advice. Gleason 10 is bad but no signes of spread is good. I would hope your dad is under the care of a top notch urologist and they are formulating a plan for treatment in the near future. In the mean time, pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book Surviving Prostate Cancer. It is considered one of the bibles on the subject. In addition, try and give as many of your dad's stats as you can so members can see his info and history( see signature of many forum members). Good luck and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Welcome to our site and sorry your husband had to join our little club. Highlander and the others have pretty much covered everything. I would only had that it is human nature to try and find the perfect example of your husbands pc and do what they did for a successful outcome. Unfortunately, each pc case is uniquely different...no two are exactly the same. You and your husband must do your research, decide on a treatment, and don't look back. There is life after pc! Good luck and stay positive ! Fran

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA and biopsy recommended - Q on Causes of elevated PSA

Posts.Content: You let me down, AZ. I thought you were the rock on this forum, and you showed a little chink in the armor....even signed your real name. Just kidding, Nancy! We all let it get to us, once in a while. I have seen my share of death and dying with 31 years as a firefighter. Most of the time I try to celebrate the saves, or the near misses. But sometimes the really tragic ones, especially young people, get to me. I have had a pretty good, sickness free life for 63 years, so a little bump in the road is nothing compared with the major mountains others have had to climb or are climbing! Like you, I continue to write on this forum to try and lighten the load of some others here, just like mine was lightened. Continue to celebrate life every day. I, for one, am a fan of how you do it! Fran

Posts.Title: Reality check...

Posts.Content: Stairs were no problem. I walk a little hunched over because of soreness from the keyhole sites. Sitting is more of a problem from bladder and balloon catheter causing pressure. Laying down is no problem. Also as mentioned get them to give you the litacaine cream for the tip of your penis...it starts getting sore pretty quickly. Good luck! Fran
Posts.Title: Home after my daVinci

Posts.Content: Think positive, Tim. With only 2 of 12 cores showing cancer, it looks like you may have caught it early. It could have been much worse! Use this time before surgery to read up on what you need to know to make it as smooth an ordeal as possible. You can also work on your diet and exercise to be in as good condition as possible before your surgery. Good luck and stay positive. Many of us on the forum have been in your position. Remember there is life after Prostate cancer. Fran

I would only had that it is human nature to try and find the perfect example of your husbands pc and do what they did for a successful outcome. Unfortunately, each pc case is uniquely different...no two are exactly the same. You and your husband must do your research, decide on a treatment, and don't look back. There is life after pc! Good luck and stay positive ! Fran
Posts.Signature: BD 1950 DRE in 2005 showed right lobe enlarged/hard Biopsies in 2006 and 2009 both negative Biopsy May 2013 positive 1 of 14 cores 4+3=7 T2a. PSA 2.9 daVinci surgery 7/17/13 by Dr. Dennis LaRock Final pathology 7/29/13 Tumor size 1.5 cm PC found on both lobes (biopsy indicated one) T2b Gleason 4+3=7 Negative margins first post surgery psa 8/30/13 undetectable second post surgery psa 11/23/13 undetectable 18 month post surgery psa 2/17/15 undetectable 5 year post surgery psa 3/20/18 undetectable
Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Fasteddie is right. It is amazing how different everyone's PC is! That makes the decision making so much more difficult. At 62 and having detected my PC reasonably early, my choice was to take advantage of that and have it removed. There are other choices that may work for you both physically and emotionally. Do your research, decide on a course of action and then go for it and don't look back. Good luck and keep us informed. The troops here will be behind you no matter what you decide! Fran

Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: I'm with Jerseyguy. PSA test in 6 months along with a DRE looking for abnormalities (preferably with the same doctor). If nothing, repeat in 6 months. If something significant repeat the biopsy. If nothing repeat the entire procedure in 6 months. Just like a little flow chart. LOL That pretty much was my course of action over 5 years. Third biopsy found G7 cancer early enough that surgery has me cancer free (fingers crossed). Good luck and stay positive.

Posts.Title: Further action following testing for P.C

Posts.Content: You let me down, AZ. I thought you were the rock on this forum, and you showed a little chink in the armor....even signed your real name. Just kidding, Nancy! We all let it get to us, once in a while. I have seen my share of death and dying with 31 years as a firefighter. Most of the time I try to celebrate the saves, or the near misses. But sometimes the really tragic ones, especially young people, get to me. I have had a pretty good, sickness free life for 63 years, so a little bump in the road is nothing compared with the major mountains others have had to climb or are climbing! Like you, I continue to write on this forum to try and lighten the load of some others here, just like mine was lightened. Continue to celebrate life every day. I, for one, am a fan of how you do it! Fran

Posts.Title: I`m Done #37 on Wednesday!

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club but sorry your diagnosis made you a member. If you can give more info on your situation like values of your PSA tests and Gleason score of your biopsy, the troops can chime in more accurately. In any event, your PSA can fluctuate for a variety of reasons between tests for anything that stimulates the prostate like sex, DRE by your doctor, certain activities like bike riding, etc. Also, certain foods and drugs can play a role in fluctuations. It looks like you are doing active surveillance so continued success and stay positive. Fran

Posts.Title: Further action following testing for P.C

Posts.Content: Hang in there Bomber, it takes an incredibly long time for everything to heal up. They did a major reconstruction of the plumbing in there. Your mind is over the operation far sooner than your body! It took me almost a year to the day to stop using that small pad for the occasional leak but now after 17 months, it almost like it never happened! Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Content: Glad to see you are doing OK, Shittingbricks! Sorry to hear of your fellow firefighters problems and the death of your comrade! I see your G score was upgraded after surgery. I am sure you are probably glad you didn't do AS considering this turn of events. I too am a firefighter in the USA. Volunteer FF for 34 years now and still going strong. I was out of work for about 3 weeks and didn't go back to answering fire calls until 6 weeks. Hope you are back and at full strength! Good luck, stay safe, and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: On a not so lighter note....

Posts.Content: The biopsy is just a tool to help evaluate the potential for cancer, like the PSA test and the DRE. I am wondering if you allowed your doctor to perform the DRE and if so, what the results were. It is the results of this test, along with PSA results that drove my three biopsies that eventually found G7 cancer. Did your doctor identify something during the DRE that triggered her advice for a biopsy? You sound like someone who is willing to roll the dice and hope the odds are in your favor. I wish you luck with that. I, for one, aren't willing to let luck play any roll in my health. Fran

Posts.Title: I refused the biopsy. Urologist not happy and arrogant...

Posts.Content: Hello Blueox, we are neighbors! I live in Swansea, Ma. and had my surgery on 7/17/13. I had mine done locally and about 5 miles from where I live so travel wasn't an issue for me. I too am very pleased with how things have gone. My incontinence is starting to come around after 12 days of catheterization. How is you urine control going and if you would give your age. As for the travel question, I would avoid longer travel for a few days. Sitting was quite difficult for a number of weeks and remains a little sore even now almost a month post surgery. Reclining worked the best for me ( and still does) to eliminate direct pressure on the area where all the plumbing was rearranged. Good luck! Fran

Posts.Title: Travel

Posts.Content: Howdy! I'm guessing (and hoping) my incontinence issues lingering are related to my age and the long catheter stay. My doctor, who I have great confidence in, is for the longer catheterization. He wanted two weeks and I kind of talked him in to 12 days. I am seeing steady improvement, but because I had urinary and erection issues before surgery, I expect some to return post surgery and we'll deal with them as best we can. I returned to work 1/2 days after three weeks and other than filling up a number of Depends every day, feel great. Night time I stay dry but have to empty my bladder three to four times a night as muscles can' t hold back much volume yet. Sorry you had to join the club at 46, but you're lucky to have found it early and here's to remaining cancer free for many years to come!

Posts.Title: Home after my daVinci

Posts.Content: Stairs were no problem. I walk a little hunched over because of soreness from the keyhole sites. Sitting is more of a problem from bladder and balloon catheter causing pressure. Laying down is no problem. Also as mentioned get them to give you the litacaine cream for the tip of your penis...it starts getting sore pretty quickly. Good luck! Fran

Posts.Title: Scans and Xrays

Posts.Content: That's pretty good news, Sam. Did they do a psa in September and if so what was it? Do you have other symptoms of enlarged prostate like weak stream, need to go often at night, etc., and any ED problems? What did your DRE show and does your urologist agree that AS is an option for you? Walt, our token AS guy here would say you are a good candidate for AS. That does mean actively testing periodically to determine what is going on. Good luck and stay positive! Fran

Posts.Title: Question on soreness after operation

Posts.Content: The biopsy is just a tool to help evaluate the potential for cancer, like the PSA test and the DRE. I am wondering if you allowed your doctor to perform the DRE and if so, what the results were. It is the results of this test, along with PSA results that drove my three biopsies that eventually found G7 cancer. Did your doctor identify something during the DRE that triggered her advice for a biopsy? You sound like someone who is willing to roll the dice and hope the odds are in your favor. I wish you luck with that. I, for one, aren't willing to let luck play any roll in my health. Fran

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Keep an eye on it and continue to have dre's looking for abnormalities. As far as your surgeon, most here recommend that you find one that has done at least 500 daVinci prostatectemies....Welcome cmcona, sorry to hear you are joining our club. To the question of considering surgery, I would recommend that you find a surgeon you trust and go for it....I was pleasantly surprised to be able to walk out of the hospital the day after my surgery and would recommend it to anyone. I didn't have the balls before surgery, but after, I watched the surgery on YouTube and in the hands of a skilled surgeon the robot is an amazing tool....As far as your surgeon, most here recommend that you find one that has done at least 500 daVinci prostatectemies. As Highlander, an administrator here who is sure to chime in, likes to say, you only get one shot at this!...You have gotten some great advise from some of our distinguished members. I would add that if you decide on a surgeon or facility for surgery, schedule it asap so you will have a slot reserved....If you have the means, there are many here who would suggest you search out the best urologist to do your surgery, even if it means traveling to John Hopkins or a similar center of excellence. One that has thousands of surgeries under his belt....To the question of considering surgery, I would recommend that you find a surgeon you trust and go for it. There are many stories here of men who chose to wait and found out later that more aggressive cancer was missed on biopsy and/or it had spread outside the prostate putting them in a worse predicament....I had the daVinci and am very happy with the results. If you have the means, there are many here who would suggest you search out the best urologist to do your surgery, even if it means traveling to John Hopkins or a similar center of excellence....I had what I considered a very conscientious and experienced urologist who I trusted enough to do my surgery and believe he has got me cancer free. They do exist and I would suggest you find yourself one....If there is any chance that it is still organ confined, I would guess your urologist will suggest surgery....If there is any chance that it is still organ confined, I would guess your urologist will suggest surgery. Surgery is delayed until 6-8 weeks after a biopsy to allow the prostate to heal....
